instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
customer plugged usb hub and apparently has killed the board.

i found out <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is shorted, i then removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>  and can confirmed <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is definitely shorted.  

i then injected 5v to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> but nothing gets warm. also my psu has limited 5v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> to 1.7v :(

i think it might have killed the CPU via <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7310</CHIP>

any suggestion??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
If there is very low value to ground, start injecting with 1V.
Monitor the current and go up, maintaining ampers bellow power limit; set its limits to max (5-10A).
If you start with 5V, power supply can get blocked reaching ampers limit and will not inject anything...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
I did start from 1v. but with 2.4v - 4v its drawing 1.7v @ 5.76amp and nothing get warm.


gonna put this board back to the bottom of the pile. i'll get 10AMP power supply someday.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
If you have 5A bench power supply indicating 5.76A, is already blocked; it doesn't inject anything in that moment, nor even 1.7V.
Maintain current under 5A (at limit) and check voltage on the board with DMM.
1.4V/5A (as example) means 7W which should heat something.
Unless you lose power on the leads connected between power supply and MLB; use strong wires.

Also remove any heatsink from the board.
CPU will not heat so easy, as it has many contacts with the board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message: Yes, when i inject any voltage then check with a multimeter on the board, it only taking 0.3v.  I?ll try again in a bit. Thank you :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
is it wise to remove the <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>, so the bench power supply can concentrate the board without CPU?

so far i've removed <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR> (power to cam), R19920 (SPI stuff) only left to remove are the 3 CPU PHASES.

after i removed the three PHASES, can i try inject more than 5v to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>?

i think the short is inside the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
it was the cpu phases, not sure which one tho.

[B]Got a Fan spin BABY!!!![/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
mmm, the board is working now after replaced the two phases with FDMF6708N.

but no backlight. yes got an image. 0v on pin1. fuse is good.
probably a dead <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> driver...
need to check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> first...

got 2 known working MacBook pro 15" display assembly here,


do you know if i can use a 13" 2015 screen for testing?
15" is too big to work with. like 11" Air screen works on 13" logic board vice versa.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message: Yes you can use 13? and 15? as long as they are 2015 screens

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 46482"]Yes you can use 13? and 15? as long as they are 2015 screens [/QUOTE]

thanks for the info.

the backlight is now fixed. i was right, <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> was the culprit.

now i'll do the testing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
boot to apple logo, a quarter of the way then laptop reboot.

i used FDMF6708 on <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> and left the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> with original FDMF6808.  can this be a problem?

or can it be something else, replace everything that use PP5V??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. RIP CPU?
threads.message:
mmm, can boot to OSX fine from the internal SSD but not an external USB boot drive. the original problem was a USB hub killed the logic board which makes perfect sense.
however USB port does work, i can browse a USB drive perfectly fine.

starting to hate this board.
